value.title: Southampton trials facial recognition cameras in pubs and clubs
value.excerpt: Facial recognition cameras are being trialled to help stop those banned from pubs and clubs gaining access. The scheme, which is taking place in Southampton, is running for three months across six venues.

value.title: How did facial recognition technology send the wrong man to jail where he was brutally attacked?
value.excerpt: One Houston man is suing after he claims facial recognition software caused him to be falsely arrested and attacked in jail.

value.title: AI facial recognition software concerns
value.excerpt: A Houston man who was falsely identified by facial recognition software was thrown in jail, and violently attacked, but how did it happen? FOX 26's Damali Keith reports more.

value.title: Texas man sues Macy’s and Sunglass Hut parent over wrongful arrest linked to facial recognition
value.excerpt: A Texas man is suing Macy’s and the parent company of Sunglass Hut after the two companies allegedly relied on error-prone facial recognition technology to falsely accuse him of armed robbery.

value.title: Is Facial Recognition a Useful Public Safety Tool or Something Sinister?
value.excerpt: In August 2023, the Chinese government issued draft regulations that aim to limit the private use of facial recognition technologies; the rules impose no such restrictions on its use for "national security" concerns.

value.title: When One Man Used Computer Vision To Reassemble Shredded Bank Notes
value.excerpt: Clearly manual re-assembly is a challenging task. But now Chung Kong, a PhD student at Hong Kong University, has shown that computer vision can help reassemble shredded notes at least partially. Kong became intrigued after noticing that the Hong Kong ...

value.title: Corydon: Five arrests after Met Police uses live facial recognition
value.excerpt: The Metropolitan Police has arrested five people after using Live Facial Recognition (LFR) technology in south London. The force said it deployed the technology in Croydon on 19 January as part of its work to "reduce serious violence". Civil liberties organisation Liberty called the Met's use of the technology "deeply concerning".

value.title: Cops Used DNA to Predict a Suspect’s Face—and Tried to Run Facial Recognition on It
value.excerpt: Leaked records reveal what appears to be the first known instance of a police department attempting to use facial recognition on a face generated from crime-scene DNA. It likely won’t be the last.

value.title: Face recognition technology follows a long analog history of surveillance and control based on identifying physical features- The Conversation
value.excerpt: Face recognition software is only the most recent manifestation of global systems of tracking and sorting. Precursors are rooted in the now-debunked belief that bodily features offer a unique index to character and identity. This pseudoscience was formalized in the late 18th century under the rubric of the ancient practice of physiognomy.

value.title: Apple Vision Pro Sold Out, At Least For Pre-Order

value.title: Face recognition technology follows a long analog history of surveillance and control based on identifying physical features
value.excerpt: Face recognition technology follows earlier biometric surveillance techniques, including fingerprints, passport photos and iris scans. It’s the first that can be done without the subject’s knowledge.

value.title: Sam’s Club Deploys AI-Powered Computer Vision to Speed Payment Confirmation
value.excerpt: Sam’s Club is piloting tech designed to address a big customer pain point: waiting for an associate to check their receipt against the items in their cart.

value.title: Sam’s Club is testing out AI, computer vision tech to speed up exit process at stores
value.excerpt: Pilots are currently underway at 10 Sam’s Club locations and involves a combination of computer vision and digital technology which captures images of carts and verifies payment for all the items in the shopper’s possession.
